messageBody:
Dave Bender wrote:

> We're migrating a Java web application from one vendor's database to
> another. The web application was nicely designed to require us to make a
> change in just one spot to change the datastore. But I'm puzzled, then,
> about how to do testing to verify that the results from the database
> interactions are identical since I have to stop and start the application to
> switch databases.
>
> Does JUnit have a way to set aside one batch of objects so I can compare a
> second set of objects in another run of the test? Or am I wandering down the
> wrong road....?


1. Set up a series of tests (using hard coded results*)
2. Run the tests on db 1
3. Switch datasources
4. Run the tests on db 2

The test results should be no-fail for both datasources. This doesn't
guarantee full equivalency, of course, it only guarantees that the
subset of the database you are testing is equivalent. You could use
junit to verify that table structure/fields etc. are 100% identical, but
I'm not sure it's the ideal tool for the job. DBUnit
(http://dbunit.sourceforge.net/) may be more appropiate, though I
haven't personally used it.

A separate issue is testing whether your datasource is available,
whether the performance is equivalent etc. But that's beyond the scope
(or at least intention) of JUnit.


* If you don't want to hard code the data, or you want to run the test
repeatedly with differing sets of data you could use the much quoted
(esp. by J. B. Rainsberger ;) "Parameterized Test Case". Search the
archives.


HTH,
Jim Cheesman
